awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Analysis of Surface Water Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will develop new technical tools in partial differential equations and other branches of mathematics, and she will extend and combine existing tools, in order to tackle several long-standing open problems in theoretical aspects of water waves. They include (1) the global regularity versus finite-time blowup for the initial value problem, (2) the existence of traveling waves and their classification, (3) the stability and instability of traveling waves. Emphasis is placed upon the large scale dynamics and genuinely nonlinear behaviors, an acute understanding of which ultimately hinges upon analytical proofs. Emphasis is placed upon the use of the Euler equations in hydrodynamics rather than simple approximate models such as the Korteweg-de Vries equation. The PI proposes to foster applied mathematics at her host institution. She will continue organizing seminars and conferences, and she will disseminate her research through conference presentations, seminars and colloquia. The PI proposes to enhance the undergraduate ODE curriculum and develop new graduate courses. She plans to involve undergraduate and graduate students in her research and mentor graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The PI will encourage women and minorities to pursue careers in mathematics, science and engineering, and improve the pipeline for women research mathematicians.

The problem of water waves concerns the wave motion at the interface separating in two or three dimensions an incompressible inviscid fluid below a body of air, acted upon by gravity and possibly surface tension. Describing in an idealized fashion what may be observed in an ocean or a lake, water waves are a perfect specimen of applied mathematics. They host a wealth of wave phenomena, ranging in length scale from ripples driven by surface tension to tsunamis and to rogue waves. They provide source and inspiration to several branches of mathematics. Furthermore they impact outside of mathematics, from hydraulics to weather prediction. The water wave problem, notwithstanding, presents profound and subtle difficulties for rigorous analysis, modeling and numerical simulations. For one thing, the interface between the water and the air is a priori unknown and to be determined as part of the solution, namely a free boundary. Incidentally, free boundaries are mathematically challenging in their own right and they occur in numerous situations such as the melting of ice and the stretching of a flexible membrane over an obstacle. To make things worse, boundary conditions at the free surface are severely nonlinear.  This project will develop new tools to advance understanding of these challenging problems.

por.por_cntn:
The project has led to the resolution of some outstanding problems surrounding surface water waves. Most importantly, Zhao Yang and the PI gave a first proof of the spectral instability of Stokes waves --- periodic traveling waves in water---away from the origin of the complex plane. Numerical evidence has long suggested such instability, but a rigorous proof has been elusive, other than the well-known Benjamin--Feir instability near the origin. Also Jared Bronski, Samuel Wester and the PI discovered a novel spectral instability phenomenon for several bi-directional regualrized long-wave models --- the spectrum tending toward infinity along curves with nonzero real parts --- and offered a theoretical explanation. These results are expected to help numerical simulations and engineering applications. 

Also the PI proved the 50 years old conjecture about wave breaking for Whitham's shallow water equation. Recently, this has led to a proof of wave breaking for a range of Korteweg-de Vries equation with fractional dispersion. Also the PI proposed a heuristic model of shallow water waves, including the full dispersion of water waves and allowing bi-directional wave propagation. The model has been studied extensively. 

Sergey Dyachenko and the PI derived a nonlinear nonlocal equation for Stokes waves in constant vorticity flows, involving periodic Hilbert transform, and numerically solved the equation to discover several new wave phenomena, particularly, an unexpected and striking connection between rotational and capillary effects. Miles Wheeler and the PI took matters further to prove rigorously that the celebrated Crapper's capillary wave in an irrotational flow makes the profile of a periodic traveling wave in a constant vorticity flow, when gravitational acceleration is negligible, and there exist overhangin and touching Stokes waves in constant vorticity flows. By contrast, in an irrotational flow, the profile is necessarily the graph of a single-valued function. 

Bryan Clark, Zhizhen Zhao and the PI mentored Illinois physics students, developing gauge-invariant autoregressive neural networks for several quantum lattice models and, also, second-order optimization methods for quantum dynamics models in higher dimensions.
